  physical_appearance: This is a batik kain panjang. On the left vertical panel
 it features rows of opposing and interlocking triangles. The triangles and its flanking borders are densely decorated with fishes
 flowers
 and birds. The main body of this batik features bats interspersed amongst flowers
 with birds lining the top and bottom. There is a signature at the top-left of this batik kain panjang.

  subject_terms_1: Peranakan birds (motifs) flower (motif) cultural diffusion symbolism

  subject_terms_2: Motifs Ethnic costume Peranakan (Asian people) Culture diffusion Symbolism Batik

  subject_terms_3: Peranakan costumes Batik

  sgcool_label_text: Rows of opposing and interlocking triangles
 known as tumpal occupy the broad vertical panel (kepala) of this sarong.  On the main design field or badan of this sarong
 flowers interspersed with bats (symbolising good fortune for the Chinese) and birds are repeated.  Although the buketan motif (large bouquets flowers) is a common design theme for batiks
 this sarong additionally features exotic rock formations and bird varieties.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Djien Nio (1929-1987)
 the last in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  In her earlier signatures
 she used her husband’s name
 Liem Siok Hien.  But from 1965 onwards
 she used Jane Hendromartono
 combining her husband’s new Indonesian family name
 Hendromartono with Jane
 as people addressed her by.  She developed a personal style distinct from her mother and grandmother
 and experimented with a wide spectrum of colours and exotic combinations of birds
 rock formations and mythical animals.  Jane Hendromartono’s clientele expanded beyond the elite in Indonesia to include Europe
 America and Japan
 especially in the 1980s.  This batik is signed “Jane Hendromartono © Pekalongan
 Java ‘68”

metadata.physical_appearance: This is a batik kain panjang. On the left vertical panel, it features rows of opposing and interlocking triangles. The triangles and its flanking borders are densely decorated with fishes, flowers, and birds. The main body of this batik features bats interspersed amongst flowers, with birds lining the top and bottom. There is a signature at the top-left of this batik kain panjang.
metadata.subject_terms_1: Peranakan birds (motifs) flower (motif) cultural diffusion symbolism
metadata.subject_terms_2: Motifs Ethnic costume Peranakan (Asian people) Culture diffusion Symbolism Batik
metadata.sgcool_label_text: Rows of opposing and interlocking triangles, known as tumpal occupy the broad vertical panel (kepala) of this sarong.  On the main design field or badan of this sarong, flowers interspersed with bats (symbolising good fortune for the Chinese) and birds are repeated.  Although the buketan motif (large bouquets flowers) is a common design theme for batiks, this sarong additionally features exotic rock formations and bird varieties.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Djien Nio (1929-1987), the last in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  In her earlier signatures, she used her husband’s name, Liem Siok Hien.  But from 1965 onwards, she used Jane Hendromartono, combining her husband’s new Indonesian family name, Hendromartono with Jane, as people addressed her by.  She developed a personal style distinct from her mother and grandmother, and experimented with a wide spectrum of colours and exotic combinations of birds, rock formations and mythical animals.  Jane Hendromartono’s clientele expanded beyond the elite in Indonesia to include Europe, America and Japan, especially in the 1980s.  This batik is signed “Jane Hendromartono © Pekalongan, Java ‘68”
